questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You implement Microsoft Azure Information Protection.
You need to automatically protect email messages that contain the word Confidential in the subject line.
What should you create?

discussion.content: A. a mail flow rule from the Exchange admin center

Selected Answer: A
mail flow
the word "protect" is too vague, isn't it? you can encrypt, scan, block, send for review, request approval....
Just tested this recently.. so i'm confident that it's mail flow > rules
Tested in lab. Its right answer. MAil flow rule

comments.content: for sure!

discussion.content: A is correct! mail flow rule from Exchange admin center
A. a mail flow rule from the Exchange admin center

choices.D: a sharing policy from the Exchange admin center
choices.A: a mail flow rule from the Exchange admin center
choices.C: a supervision policy from the Security & Compliance admin center
choices.B: a message trace from the Security & Compliance admin center

comments.content:
Cloud app security, Investigate. Just checked 
https://**.portal.cloudappsecurity.com/#/audits

discussion.content: Shouldn't this be C. Cloud App Security?
It's C. In the security and compliance you cannot see neither sign-ins, nor increase in per-user activity.

Selected Answer: B
Likely an outdated question - Defender for Cloud Apps by now is accessible via the Security & Compliance portal...

Selected Answer: C
https://security.microsoft.com/cloudapps/
Access from Microsoft Defender portal - Cloud apps - Activity Log - You will see Activity/User/App/IP address/Location/Device/Date

Selected Answer: C
CAS provides for sign in location as well as apps used logging mechanism

I have just tested the CAS and S&C portals. In terms of administrative effort, the Cloud App Security (now called Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps) portal definitely is by far the quickest and easiest to use. When selecting a user, I was immediately shown all activity specified in this question (in particular, increases in user activity which was my concern) which can be exported. The information shown within the Security and Compliance logs requires a little bit more effort to locate, and although this can be exported it requires more investigation.

The answer here is C - Cloud App Security (Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps).

comments.content: But you do not know the user yet, the question states investigate user activity; sure you are not going to be selecting each user to see activity.. Answer is B

discussion.content:
I have just tested the CAS and S&C portals. In terms of administrative effort, the Cloud App Security (now called Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps) portal definitely is by far the quickest and easiest to use. When selecting a user, I was immediately shown all activity specified in this question (in particular, increases in user activity which was my concern) which can be exported. The information shown within the Security and Compliance logs requires a little bit more effort to locate, and although this can be exported it requires more investigation.

The answer here is C - Cloud App Security (Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps).

Selected Answer: B
minimize administrative effort = B

Selected Answer: C
C A Sec

above link shows the list of activities. 

Answer is B

comments.content: Yes it's the least effort, but doesn't address the requirement. Searching the audit logs, or the reports in the security & compliance center, do not show details about sign-ins and application usage/trends that I can find.

discussion.content:
Least administrative effort = B

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/search-the-audit-log-in-security-and-compliance?view=o365-worldwide

I think the key here is - "..and increases in activity during the past month".
Like a graph, statistics, trends - for this, SCC would be optimal.
B is correct!

The question states minimising administrative effort, which would mean simply opening up S&C and checking the logs. 

 Having to configure CAS is not something that takes minimal effort. Nor is it readily available. 

That is why I think the answer given is correct.

Digg

comments.content:
Following up on this, you can see 'User Logged in' in S&C for the people stating this was not a capability. You can use the reports tab to see increased activity and yes you can use the Audit log search to see things like IP Address, Application etc. 

CAS Is an additional feature, not something that is ready to go.

discussion.content: The activity log in Cloud App Security (Investigate > Activity Log) provides filtering for logins (successfull, failed), user and date range. It super easy to click through. Don't know about similiar functions in Security & Compliance center.

comments.content:
It has to be Cloud App Security. Don't see similar functions in S&C audit log search. 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cloud-app-security/activity-filters

discussion.content:
Perhaps the key is "the solution must minimize administrative effort". You can search all those things at Security & Compliance center and at Cloud App Security, but the second one needs configuration (connect CAS to Microsoft cloud apps) . From Security and compliance you can search for specific activities and appears the IP address of the device. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/search-the-audit-log-in-security-and-compliance?view=o365-worldwide 
If this is a correct assumption, it would be B, as requires less effort.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You need to investigate user activity in Microsoft 365, including from where users signed in, which applications were used, and increases in activity during the past month. The solution must minimize administrative effort.
Which admin center should you use?

discussion.content:
Shouldnt it be NO YES YES ? 

File 1 should be deleted before 1st of March as it was last edited on the 16th of Jan and theres a 1 month retention period from last modified. Thus making it deleted 16th Feb.

comments.content: I got your point but there's nothing said about days. It's about month - file will be deleted next month on the same date no matter how many days that month contains. Answer is N, Y, Y imho.
NYN. For the 3rd one, the difference between the days is 28
You are correct, since files will be deleted immediately upon setting these policies. I forgot about that.

discussion.content:
I think answer is next.

N: File 1 is deleted on FEB 16
Y: File 2 is modified on Feb 5 -> deleted on Feb 25 so still available on 20
N: File 2 is modified on Feb 5 -> deleted on Feb 25 so already gone on march 5th

does this make sense?

comments.content: "On February 5, 2019, User1 edits File2."
Option 3 doesn't make sense because the file was modified on Feb 1, policy is to retain for 1 month based on last modified date, so not sure how you arrive at it being deleted on 2/25.

discussion.content: If MSFT "assumes" 30 days for a month, then this is yet another example of not thinking things through. A month is a month regardless of what they say. So, if I have a "sensitive file" that MUST be deleted after X amount of years, do I need to create some sort of calculous for the days that end in 28, or 31? That would be creating a lot of risk. I get that the link says (assume 30 days). But maybe some folks at MSFT need to go back to school. This is sloppy at best.
NYN - According to me since both files were modified before Policy1 is applied, none of them will be affected by the policy and none of them will be deleted

comments.content: Sorry, file2 is modified on Feb. 5. Feb. 20 is only 15 days after, so it is present in OneDrive, but still NYN
MS means 30 days https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/retention-settings?view=o365-worldwide#retaining-content-for-a-specific-period-of-time

discussion.content: months comes with 30,31 and 28 days... so with this in mind, when MS say a month, don't it mean the same date of the next month?
N, Y, N for me.

My answer; N,Y,N

Q1 - N: The retention policy doesn't apply to items that existed prior to the retention policy being put in place. Once the modify date changes, after the retention policy is set, then the retention time counter starts. File1 hasn't been modified, so the policy doesn't apply yet. 

Q2 - Y: File2 is modified on Feb. 5. Feb. 20 is only 15 days after, so it is present in OneDrive.

Q3 - N: File2 will still be present in OneDrive on March 5. The retention policy is enacted on files after 30 days. February has 28 days in the month. So File2 will NOT be deleted automatically unless it is not modified before, or on, March 7.

Reference: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/retention-policies-sharepoint?view=o365-worldwide

Location heading: How retention works for SharePoint and OneDrive

comments.content: Very tricky. The article states a month is 30 days, but are the people writing the test aware of that or are they not expecting us to be that exact?? Part of me feels if I stick strictly to a month is 30 days, I'll be marked incorrect, despite it being correct. Who knows.

Trying to set the policy, the below warning is displayed. As I guess, It means the policy immediately applies to all files no matter whether it is modified or not. Doesn't it? So, the right answer is YYN.
Items that are currently older than 5 years will be deleted after you turn on this policy. This is especially important to note for locations scoped to 'All' sources (for example, 'All Teams chats') because all matching items in those locations across your organization will be permanently deleted.

discussion.content:
Note when creating a retention policy:
Items that are currently older than 1 day will be deleted after this policy is enabled. Knowing this is especially important for locations that are set to "All" sources (e.g. "All Microsoft Teams Chats"), as all matching items in those locations within your organization will be permanently deleted.
Means last modified of the files, and not when the policy is created.
N-Y-Y

comments.content:
i mean 
NO 
YES

discussion.content:
NO
YES
NO

N
Y
N - Feb (28 days, not 30 days)

The correct answer is = N/ Y / Y

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/create-retention-policies?view=o365-worldwide#deleting-content-thats-older-than-a-specific-age
NO - Is a trick. On that day, the file has been deleted for a long time. - YES,YES

Y, Y, Y makes sense because you don't want to create a policy and then have hundreds of files deleted as soon as you turn on a policy. I mean, maybe you do, but generally, that's frowned upon. So I would think the process would delete files based on modify date for all file modified after the date of enablement and the enablement date for the rest. That gives you time to fix the policy if you make a mistake. Of course, files are often recoverable by MS support. It's just a headache.

comments.content: I change my vote. N, Y, Y. Files can be deleted as soon as a policy stipulating the deletion of files is created.

Should be NYY

"A retention policy can both retain and then delete items, or delete old items without retaining them.

In both cases, if your retention policy deletes items, it's important to understand that the time period specified for a retention policy is calculated from the time when the item was created or modified, and not the time since the policy was assigned."

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/create-retention-policies?view=o365-worldwide

discussion.content: it took me some time to realize the it should be NO YES YES. I first answered Y Y Y, but then I realized that File1 has a modification date of Jan 16 2019, so according to the policy it should be deleted on Feb 16 2019, hence option is is NO as the file is long gone!
No, Yes, Yes. File one should be deleted Feb 16th. File two (make sure to read the last modified date at the end of the question) will be deleted one month after its modified date.

Because the Retention Policy was created on Feb.1st 2019 and it is a one month retain and then delete policy, the earliest that anything will be deleted is March 1st 2019....anything modified after Feb 1st 2019 will be deleted after one month from the time it is modified. Therefore: Yes Yes Yes

comments.content: No Yes Yes is correct...I was wrong with my initial comment...agree with barleyhutcher
It says File2 was modified on February 5. It was modified after the policy was put in place. So it would be automatically be deleted as scheduled if no one else modifies it on March 5.

discussion.content:
Shouldn't file 2 modified Jan 20th be deleted automatically on Feb 20th? so that would make it a NO as the question is Deleted on the 5th of March.. 
?
Agree with barleyhutcher

comments.content: Under the picture ist more information that on February 5, 2019 the File2 was edited.
Remember that february has 28 days, not 30! File 2 won't be deleted on march 5

I missed that.... So N-Y-Y are appropriate solutions.
N because file 1 is last modified on Jan 16 so deleted on Feb 16
Y because file 2 is last modified on Feb 5 so available Feb 20 
Y because file 2 is last modified on Feb 5 so it's deleted Mar 5

discussion.content:
I think the correct answer is No - Yes -No
File 1 was last edited on the 16th of January, that means the retention policy will delete it on the 16th Feb
File 2 was las edited on the 20th of January, that means the retention policy will delete on the 20th February

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have a new Microsoft 365 subscription.
You need to prevent users from sending email messages that contain Personally Identifiable Information (PII).
Solution: From the Microsoft 365 compliance center, you create a data loss prevention (DLP) policy.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Correct
correct A

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses a default domain named contoso.com.
You have two users named User1 and User2.
From the Microsoft 365 compliance center, you add User1 to the eDiscovery Manager role group.
From the Microsoft 365 compliance center, User1 creates a case named Case1.
You need to ensure that User1 can add User2 as a case member. The solution must use the principle of least privilege.
To which role group should you add User2?

discussion.content: In exam 28/6/2023

"You can add or remove members to manage who can access the case. However, before a member can access an eDiscovery (Premium) case (and perform tasks in the case), you must add the user to the eDiscovery Manager role group on the Permissions page in the Microsoft Purview compliance portal."
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/add-or-remove-members-from-a-case-in-advanced-ediscovery?view=o365-worldwide

I'm going to say none of these roles since none of them have "Role Management". If this question is in the exam there will be a forth option not listed here. 


"To view the Permissions tab in the Security & Compliance Center, you need to be an admin. Specifically, you need to be assigned the Role Management role, and that role is assigned only to the Organization Management role group in the Security & Compliance Center by default. Furthermore, the Role Management role allows users to view, create, and modify role groups"

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/permissions-in-the-security-and-compliance-center?view=o365-worldwide

Selected Answer: A
Correct answer.

eDiscovery Manager - An eDiscovery Manager can use eDiscovery search tools to search content locations in the organization, and perform various search-related actions such as preview and export search results. Members can also create and manage cases in Microsoft Purview eDiscovery (Standard) and Microsoft Purview eDiscovery (Premium), add and remove members to a case, create case holds, run searches associated with a case, and access case data. eDiscovery Managers can only access and manage the cases they create. They can't access or manage cases created by other eDiscovery Managers.

eDiscoverey Administrator can do everything mentioned above, including a few extra things.
eDiscovery Manager - The answer is correct.
